Package com.github.tommyettinger.cringe

Class SimplexNoise

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.cringe.RawNoise
com.github.tommyettinger.cringe.SimplexNoise
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Json.Serializable, Externalizable, Serializable
public class SimplexNoise extends RawNoise
Simplex noise functions, in 2D, 3D, 4D, 5D, and 6D. This variety scales the result with multiplication by a constant, which isn't always guaranteed to produce a value in the -1 to 1 range for 4D, 5D, or 6D noise. Because this has to scale by a rather small constant in 4D and up, the mostly-mid-range results for those dimensions are run through a gain function that sharpens the result, making high and low values more common than they would otherwise be.
Simplex noise is very fast, especially in 2D and 3D, but loses quality somewhat in higher dimensions. It tends to look drastically better if you use it with 2 or more octaves than if you only use 1 octave.
See Also:
  • Serialized Form

    • getNoiseWithSeed

      public float getNoiseWithSeed(float x, float y, int seed)
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Gets 2D noise with a specific seed. If the seed cannot be retrieved or changed per-call, then this falls back to changing the position instead of the seed; you can check if this will happen with RawNoise.hasEfficientSetSeed().
      Overrides:
      getNoiseWithSeed in class RawNoise
      Parameters:
      x - x position; can be any finite float
      y - y position; can be any finite float
      seed - any int; must be the same between calls for the noise to be continuous
      Returns:
      a noise value between -1.0f and 1.0f, both inclusive

    • noise

      public static float noise(float x, float y, float z, float w, float u, int seed)
      Thanks to Mark A. Ropper for this implementation.
      Parameters:
      x - x coordinate
      y - y coordinate
      z - z coordinate
      w - w coordinate (4th dimension)
      u - u coordinate (5th dimension)
      seed - int value that should completely change the noise if it changes even slightly
      Returns:
      a continuous noise value between -1.0 and 1.0, both inclusive

    • hasEfficientSetSeed

      public boolean hasEfficientSetSeed()
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Returns true if this generator can be seeded with RawNoise.setSeed(int) during each call to obtain noise, or false if calling setSeed() is slow enough or allocates enough that alternative approaches should be used. You can always call setSeed() on your own, but generators that don't have any seed won't do anything, and generators that return false for this method will generally behave differently when comparing how RawNoise.getNoiseWithSeed(float, float, int) changes the seed and how setSeed() does.
      Specified by:
      hasEfficientSetSeed in class RawNoise
      Returns:
      whether RawNoise.setSeed(int) should be safe to call in every RawNoise.getNoiseWithSeed(float, int) call

    • setSeed

      public void setSeed(int seed)
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Sets the seed to the given int, if int seeds are supported. If this generator cannot be seeded, this should do nothing, and should not throw an exception. If this operation allocates or is time-intensive, then RawNoise.hasEfficientSetSeed() should return false. That method is checked in RawNoise.getNoiseWithSeed(float, int), and if it returns false, the noise call will avoid calling setSeed(). You can always at least try to set the seed, even if it does nothing or is heavy on performance, and doing it a few times each frame should typically be fine for any generator. In the case this is called thousands of times each frame, check RawNoise.hasEfficientSetSeed().
      Specified by:
      setSeed in class RawNoise
      Parameters:
      seed - an int seed, with no restrictions unless otherwise documented

    • getSeed

      public int getSeed()
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Gets the current seed of the generator, as an int. This must be implemented, but if the generator doesn't have a seed that can be expressed as an int (potentially using NumberUtils.floatToIntBits(float)), this can just return 0.
      Specified by:
      getSeed in class RawNoise
      Returns:
      the current seed, as an int

    • getTag

      public String getTag()
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Returns a String constant that should uniquely identify this RawNoise as well as possible; usually this is just the class name. If a duplicate tag is already registered and RawNoise.Serializer.register(RawNoise) attempts to register the same tag again, a message is printed to System.err. The default implementation returns the String (NO), which is already registered in Serializer to a null value. Implementing this is required for any usage of Serializer.
      Specified by:
      getTag in class RawNoise
      Returns:
      a short String constant that identifies this RawNoise type

    • stringSerialize

      public String stringSerialize()
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Produces a String that describes everything needed to recreate this RawNoise in full. This String can be read back in by RawNoise.stringDeserialize(String) to reassign the described state to another RawNoise. The syntax here should always start and end with the ` (backtick) character, which is typically used by RawNoise.stringDeserialize(String) to identify the portion of a String that can be read back. The ` character should not be otherwise used unless to serialize another RawNoise that this uses.
      Specified by:
      stringSerialize in class RawNoise
      Returns:
      a String that describes this RawNoise for serialization
      See Also:
      • RawNoise.Serializer wraps this method so registered RawNoise types can be deserialized.

    • stringDeserialize

      public SimplexNoise stringDeserialize(String data)
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Given a serialized String produced by RawNoise.stringSerialize(), reassigns this RawNoise to have the described state from the given String. The serialized String must have been produced by the same class as this object is.
      Specified by:
      stringDeserialize in class RawNoise
      Parameters:
      data - a serialized String, typically produced by RawNoise.stringSerialize()
      Returns:
      this RawNoise, after being modified (if possible)
      See Also:
      • RawNoise.Serializer uses this method to deserialize any registered RawNoise type.

The readExternal method must read the values in the same sequence and with the same types as were written by writeExternal.

    • copy

      public SimplexNoise copy()
      Description copied from class: RawNoise
      Creates a copy of this RawNoise, which should be a deep copy for any mutable state but can be shallow for immutable types such as functions. This almost always just calls a copy constructor.
      The default implementation throws an UnsupportedOperationException only. Implementors are strongly encouraged to implement this in general, and that is required to use an RawNoise class with RawNoise.Serializer.
      Specified by:
      copy in class RawNoise
      Returns:
      a copy of this RawNoise
